list.text: Basic visual depiction of consumer's problem. Illustrates Budget *set*, movable bundle with upper contour sets (3), toggle ICs (4), toggle on MRS for tangency (5), toggle on optimal consumption with IC (6).   Note: adjust utility, demand, MRS in (2)
Creator: Joshua B. Miller, Department of Economics, University of Melbourne, joshua.benjamin.miller@gmail.com, https://www.joshua-benjamin-miller.com/
*careful with displayed quantities, they are rounded for display purposes, check folders for precision
Type of utility:  See Folder #2 below: 1 for Cobb-Douglas production function, 2 for Quasilinear utility, 3 for Power Utility (x^r+y^r), 4 for CES, 5 for Perfect Complements
Define prices of both goods and budget
Budget set is defined as area below the curve:
Ratio of the two prices:
Show maximal quantities allowed by budget set
Utility, either 1 for Cobb-Douglas production function or 2 for Quasilinear utility. Is flexible to function definition - need to change f-n itself and optimal solution below
Utility function - separate definition for each type of utility, combined together using Choice function:
Cobb Douglas utility:
Use buttons below to adjust QuasiLinear parameters to be illustrative:
Convex corner solutions
MRS is increasing in good 2, doesn't depend on good 1
MRS at bottom right (all good 1) is less that the price so buy more good 1
MRS at top left (all good 2) is still less than the price

For quasi linear utility, there may exist a corner solution. It happens when numerically calculated inner X or Y fall below 0. Below we implement functions for inner solution and then compare it to zero and utility at corners.
"Power" utility (nearly CES)
using this result for the limit as r-> 0: https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/115428/limit-of-lp-norm-when-p-to0

Parameters from 2.4

Demand - separate definition for each type of utility, combined together using Choice function:
